column1: For a long time there was none
column2: beyond the voice of a weak bird singing a trite old evening song that might doubtless have been heard on the hill at the same hour
column6: at any sunset of that season for centuries untold. But as they approached the village sundry distant shouts and rattles reached their ears from some elevated spot in that direction
column7: as yet screened from view by foliage. When the outlying houses of Weydon-Priors could just be described
column8: the family group was met by a turnip-hoer with his hoe on his shoulder
column9: and his dinner-bag suspended from it. The reader promptly glanced up."Any trade doing here?" he asked phlegmatically
column10: designating the village in his van by a wave of the broadsheet. And thinking the labourer did not understand him
column12: "Anything in the hay-trussing line?"The turnip-hoer had already begun shaking his head. "Why
column14: what wisdom's in him that 'a should come to Weydon for a job of that sort this time o' year?"
